Concert Orchestra – Thomas Wilkins, conductor
description: Repertoire  Bonds: The Montgomery Variations (1964)Barnes: Kinsfolknem (2024)Dawson: Negro Folk Symphony (1934/53)  About the ConductorThomas Wilkins is principal conductor of the Hollywood Bowl Orchestra, artistic partner for education and external engagement and Germeshausen Family and Youth Concerts Conductor Chair with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and professor of music (conducting) at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music, where he holds the Henry A. Upper Chair of Orchestral Conducting, established by the late Barbara and David Jacobs as a part of Indiana University's Matching the Promise Campaign. He is also music director laureate of the Omaha Symphony, where he was music director from 2005 through 2021, and principal guest conductor of the Virginia Symphony Orchestra. Past positions have included resident conductor of the Detroit Symphony and the Florida Orchestra (Tampa Bay) and associate conductor of the Richmond (Virginia) Symphony. He also has served on the music faculties of North Park University (Chicago), University of Tennessee in Chattanooga, and Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond. Devoted to promoting a life-long enthusiasm for music, Wilkins brings energy and commitment to audiences of all ages. He is hailed as a master at communicating and connecting with audiences. He has guest conducted orchestras throughout the United States. Wilkins' commitment to community has been demonstrated by his participation on several boards of directors, including the Greater Omaha Chamber of Commerce, the Charles Drew Health Center (Omaha), the Center Against Spouse Abuse in Tampa Bay, and the Museum of Fine Arts as well as the Academy Preparatory Center both in St. Petersburg, Florida. Currently, he serves as chairman of the board for the Raymond James Charitable Endowment Fund and as National Ambassador for the non-profit World Pediatric Project, headquartered in Richmond, Virginia, which provides children throughout Central America and the Caribbean with critical surgical and diagnostic care. A native of Norfolk, Virginia, Wilkins is a graduate of the Shenandoah Conservatory of Music and the New England Conservatory of Music (Boston). He and his wife, Sheri-Lee, are the proud parents of twin daughters, Erica and Nicole.

title: Arbor Day Tree Planting at Rogers Family Park
location: Rogers Family Park, 2000 E Winslow Rd, Bloomington, IN 47401, USA
description:
Celebrate Arbor Day in Indiana on the last Friday in April and continue Bloomington's tree-planting tradition! 

Friday, April 24 from 9 a.m.-noon at Rogers Family Park, 2000 E. Winslow Rd. in Bloomington

Assist Parks and Recreation urban forestry staff as they plant trees along the Jackson Creek Trail, and take home a free tree seedling while supplies last. Tree planting volunteers will help dig and widen holes to plant balled and burlapped trees, move trees into planting position, and spread mulch. Volunteers ages 14 yrs. and older are welcome! 

Gloves and shovels are provided; meet at the red barn at Rogers Family Park. Vehicle parking is available inside the entrance to Rogers Family Park south of the Winslow-High-Rogers roundabout. Additional vehicle parking is available at Sherwood Oaks Park and at Olcott Park.

Wind Ensemble – Donald McKinney, conductor
description: Repertoire  Shuying Li: In This Breath (2025, consortium premiere)John Corigliano: Gazebo Dances (1972/73)Quinn Mason: A Joyous Trilogy (2019/22)Erik Santos: The Seer (2019)*  *Voice soloist to be announced  About the ConductorDonald J. McKinney is professor of music in bands, director of bands, and chair of the Bands Department at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music. He was previously director of bands, professor of conducting, and chair of the conducting area at the University of Colorado Boulder College of Music. Prior to his 2013 appointment at CU Boulder, he was the director of wind ensembles and associate professor at Louisiana State University. McKinney has held additional faculty positions at Interlochen Arts Academy and Duquesne University Mary Pappert School of Music. From 2010 to 2015, he was the coordinator of bands for the renowned Interlochen Arts Camp, where he conducted the World Youth Wind Symphony and administered the summer band program. As a guest conductor, he has appeared with the Dallas Winds, Concordia Santa Fe, Boulder Philharmonic Orchestra, Greater Boulder Youth Orchestra, and numerous honor ensembles. His performances with the Dallas Winds have been featured on National Public Radio's Performance Today on numerous occasions. As a teacher of conducting, he has presented conducting master classes at a host of colleges and universities. His recording credits include projects with the Dallas Winds, University of Michigan Symphony Band, University of Texas Wind Ensemble, University of North Texas Wind Symphony, Keystone Wind Ensemble, and the Duquesne University Wind Symphony. He was nominated for a 2019 Grammy Award for producing the Dallas Winds recording John Williams at the Movies. He has published articles in numerous conducting resources, including five volumes of Teaching Music through Performance in Band and The Conductor's Companion. He has also authored a chapter about Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Jennifer Higdon for the book Women of Influence in Contemporary Music. McKinney earned a Doctor of Musical Arts in Conducting degree from the University of Michigan. His primary conducting teachers include Michael Haithcock, Jack Stamp, and Robert Cameron as well as additional study with H. Robert Reynolds and Frank Battisti.

title: Spring Ephemerals Hike
location: Leonard Springs Nature Park, 4685 S Leonard Springs Rd, Bloomington, IN 47403, USA
description:
There is a participation fee for this program, and pre-registration is required.
Register online by 4/23 at https://webtrac.bloomington.in.gov/webtrac/web/search.html?Primarycode=140014

Enjoy the dawning of a new spring as we hike through Leonard Springs, admiring the first flowering ephemerals! Lasting a very short time, this group of flowers brings the first nectar to our emerging pollinators, and restores the promise of a new season. We will discuss the folklore behind many of the names as we reconnect with the greening forest. Please wear sturdy shoes comfortable for hiking. Participants must be able to go up and down 100 stairs.

$5/person/in-city, $6/person/non-city

title: Drop-in Tours and Crafting
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Featured Exhibitions Gallery, First Floor
description: An Immersive ExperienceInspired by Indonesia's spectacular coral reefs, acclaimed fiber artist Mulyana (b. 1984, Bandung, Indonesia) invites you to wander through a handcrafted seascape where art and ecology meet.  Explore colorful coral reefs, playful fish, and fantastical sea creatures — all meticulously hand-knit and crocheted.  Pause to reflect on the delicate balance between human wellbeing and the vitality of our oceans.  Chat with a Museum Guide to deepen your understanding.  Create Your Own Sea CreatureEnjoy a hands-on activity in the gallery.  No prior experience is needed — a volunteer can guide you step by step.  Choose from a fish, octopus, lobster, sea urchin, or crab.  All supplies are provided, so you can dive right in!  Why Visit? This exhibition is more than art — it's a living conversation about beauty, fragility, and our shared responsibility to protect the ocean. Whether you're an art lover, a family looking for a creative activity, or simply curious, Vital Ecosystems offers a memorable experience for all ages.

title: University Orchestra – Jeffery Meyer, conductor; Tichina Vaughn, mezzo-soprano
description: Repertoire  Quinn Mason: Serenade (2025)Jessie Montgomery: Five Freedom Songs (2018)John Adams: Shaker Loops (1978/83)About the Artists  Distinguished for insightful performances, visionary programming, and wide-ranging collaborations, conductor Jeffery Meyer has captivated audiences around the globe. He is professor of orchestral conducting at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music as well as artistic partner with the Northwest Sinfonietta, one of the northwest United States' most vibrantly creative ensembles. Artistic director of the St. Petersburg Chamber Philharmonic for two decades, his work with the orchestra was noted for its breadth and innovation. His programming has earned three ASCAP Awards for Adventurous Programming and two Vytautas Marijošius Memorial Awards. A champion of contemporary music, Meyer imagines the orchestra experience as a forum for story, emotion, and civic dialogue. His projects have paired symphonic works with multimedia visionaries and diverse cultural collaborators. His recordings span repertoire from baroque to the present; his most recent, Illuminations: Music of Narong Prangcharoen, was released by Albany Records in 2023. Recent highlights include a multimedia Rite of Spring and Petrushka with the Thailand Philharmonic; Carlos Simon's Graffiti with renowned graffiti artists; a theatrical symphonic concert developed in collaboration with Daniel Bernard Roumain and Marc Bamuthi Joseph; Laura Kaminsky's Piano Concerto with Ursula Oppens (Cedille Records); a semistaged production of Nkeiru Okoye's Invitation to a Die-In; and multiple collaborations with the American Composers Orchestra's EarShot program. Recent and upcoming engagements include the City Chamber Orchestra of Hong Kong, Los Angeles Ballet, Xalapa Symphony, Orquesta Juvenil Universitaria Eduardo Mata, American Composers Orchestra, Texas Festival Orchestra at Round Top, and returns to the Grossman Ensemble, Sichuan Symphony, and Thailand Philharmonic. Passionate about working with young musicians and music education, Meyer is an active adjudicator, guest clinician, and master class teacher. Prior to his appointment at the Jacobs School, he led acclaimed orchestral programs at Arizona State University and Ithaca College. He has given master classes throughout the United States, Canada, Europe, and Asia. Meyer holds degrees in piano and composition and earned his Doctor of Musical Arts in Piano Performance with Gilbert Kalish at Stony Brook University.Tichina Vaughn is associate professor of music in voice at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music. A Grammy Award-winning American mezzo-soprano, celebrated for her "superb, rich singing" and serious "theatrical presence," Vaughn began her international operatic career as a member of the Metropolitan Opera's Lindemann Young Artist Program. Recent successes have included her debut at the Welsh National Opera as Zia Principessa and Zita (Il Trittico), her Royal Opera House Covent Garden debut as the Witch (Hansel and Gretel), Azucena (Il Trovatore) for Piedmont Opera, as well as returning to the Metropolitan Opera as the Hostess of the Inn (Boris Gudonow), and roles in Dialogues de Carmélites, Elektra, and Porgy and Bess. Upcoming engagements include her return to the Semperoper as the Old Lady in Candide, mezzo soloist in Verdi's Requiem with the Flagstaff Symphony Orchestra, and Maria in Porgy and Bess with the Metropolitan Opera. Further international engagements have included appearances with Alan Gilbert at the Lucerne Festival in Porgy and Bess and her debut at the Opéra National de Lyon as Old Lady (Candide). In North America, Vaughn recently appeared as Amneris (Aida) at Fort Worth Opera and Cincinnati Opera and made her Opera Theatre of Saint Louis debut as Monisha in Scott Joplin's Treemonisha. From 2010 to 2018 she was an ensemble member at the Semperoper Dresden, where she was heard as Herodias (Salome), Azucena (Il Trovatore), Venus (Tannhäuser), Ulrica (Un Ballo in Maschera), and Ortrud (Lohengrin), among others. From 1996 to 2006 she was a principal artist at the Stuttgart State Opera, where she was awarded the title of Kammersängerin for her successes in such roles as Eboli (Don Carlo), Widow Begbick (Mahagonny), Venus (Tannhäuser), Giulietta (Tales of Hoffmann), Arnalta (L'incoronazione di Poppea), Fricka (Die Walküre), Waltraute (Götterdämmerung), and Erda (Siegfried and Das Rheingold). Her discography includes the Grammy-winning Metropolitan Opera recording of Porgy and Bess, Stuttgart State Theater's Der Ring des Nibelungen, and her solo CD, Christmas at My House.

description: Repertoire  Julia Wolfe: Tell me everything (1994)Yuting Tan: Amnesia (2023)Emma Cardon-Wake: GIRLHOOD (2025, premiere)*  *Georgina Joshi Composition CommissionAbout the ConductorDavid Dzubay's compositions have been performed in the United States, Europe, Canada, Mexico, and Asia by the symphony orchestras of Aspen, Atlanta, Baltimore, Boston, Cincinnati, Detroit, Fort Wayne, Guangxi, Guiyang, Honolulu, Kansas City, Louisville, Memphis, Minnesota, Oregon, Oakland, St. Louis and Vancouver; the American Composers Orchestra, National Symphonies of Ireland and Mexico, New World Symphony, National Repertory Orchestra, and New York Youth Symphony; and ensembles including the Grossman Ensemble, Le Nouvel Ensemble Moderne, Onix, Manhattan and St. Louis Brass Quintets, Voices of Change, the Alexander, Orion and Pacifica string quartets, the League/ISCM, Earplay, and the San Francisco Contemporary Music Players. His music has been championed by conductors including James DePreist, George Hanson, Keith Lockhart, David Loebel, Michael Morgan, Eiji Oue, Richard Pittman, Iván del Prado, Mark Russell Smith, Lawrence Leighton Smith, Michael Stern, Carl Topilow, David Wiley, Kirk Trevor, Thomas Wilkins, and David Zinman. Honors include two Fromm Music Foundation commissions; Guggenheim, MacDowell, Yaddo, Copland House, and Djerassi fellowships; the Kuhmo Chamber Music Festival Composition Competition, Indianapolis Chamber Orchestra Composition Competition, Utah Arts Festival Commission, William Revelli and Walter Beeler Memorial Prizes, Wayne Peterson Prize; and grants from the Aaron Copland Fund for Music for two portrait CDs. Currently professor of music and director of the New Music Ensemble at the Indiana University Jacobs School of Music in Bloomington, Dzubay was previously on the faculty of the University of North Texas in Denton. Since 2011, he has taught composition for three weeks each summer at the Brevard Music Center. From 1995 to 1998, he served as composer-consultant to the Minnesota Orchestra and during the 2005-06 season, he was Meet the Composer/American Symphony Orchestra League Music Alive Composer-in-Residence with the Green Bay Symphony Orchestra. Dzubay has conducted at the Tanglewood, Aspen, and June in Buffalo festivals as well as the National Symphony of Columbia, Grossman Ensemble, League of Composers Orchestra, Pittsburgh New Music Ensemble, Music from China, and Voices of Change.The Georgina Joshi Composition Commission Award  A vision of Louise Addicott-Joshi and made possible by a gift from The Georgina Joshi Foundation, the annual Georgina Joshi Composition Commission is awarded to a student composer in support of a new work for solo voice and instrumental ensemble to be premiered and recorded by the New Music Ensemble. The award is presented in conjunction with the Composition Department's annual Dean's Prizes.Georgina Joshi earned her bachelor's degree in music (with honors) from the Royal College of Music in London and pursued a master's degree in the Jacobs School of Music. While at IU, Joshi appeared as a soloist in major choral performances and IU Opera Theater productions. An enthusiastic performer, she was featured in a variety of regional ensembles and festivals, and appeared as a soloist in England, Wales, Romania, and Greece.

title: Tour of Thomas Hart Benton's Indiana Murals
location: AUDITORIUM - Room Number: Hall of Murals
description: This tour visitsThe Hall of Murals at IU Auditorium  IU Cinema  Woodburn Hall  About the Indiana Murals:  Thomas Hart Benton was commissioned to paint murals depicting Indiana history for the Indiana state pavilion at the 1933 World's Fair in Chicago. The dramatic 250-foot long mural, which originally wrapped around the entire exhibition hall at the World's Fair, depicts the social, economic, and cultural history of Indiana from mound building to the 1930s. After several years of storage following the fair, the panels were given to Indiana University in 1938, where they were installed in three locations on the Bloomington campus. About Your Guide:  Jim Davis is a Senior Lecturer in the Kelley School of Business, in the department of Management and Entrepreneurship. He has been serving as a docent and museum guide at the IU Eskenazi Museum of Art for the past ten years.     Know Before You GoThis tour visits three locations on campus. Please let us know if an elevator and wheelchair accessible route will be needed.   Plan to arrive at least 5 minutes beforehand to check in.For a discounted parking rate for the Indiana Memorial Union parking lot, visit the Eskenazi Museum of Art before or after this tour and ask Guest Services, at the Information Desk on the first floor, to stamp your parking voucher.

description:
Constellation Stage & Screen presents “Finn: A New Musical- At the PB&J Cafe,” on stage May 1-17 at the Waldron Auditorium.

From the creator of Doc McStuffins and Vampirina, Finn is a heartwarming musical adventure about a young shark on the brink of growing up. As he prepares to join the fearsome Shark Guard, Finn can’t shake the feeling that he’s different from the other sharks. Deep inside, he discovers a colorful fish inside him—a part of himself that longs to sparkle, sing, and dance. As Finn embarks on a journey of self-discovery, friendship, and adventure, he finds the courage to be himself! Fun for all ages!

Pollinator Habitat Workshop Day 1 of 2
location: Switchyard Park, 1601 S Rogers St, Bloomington, IN 47403, USA
description:
Participation is free but registration is required; register by April 27 online at https://webtrac.bloomington.in.gov/webtrac/web/search.html?Primarycode=140012
For ages 15 yrs. and up.
Learn how to restore pollinator habitat with the Bloomington Parks and Recreation Urban Greenspace team and biologists from the US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) Partners for Fish and Wildlife (PFW) Program. Topics to be covered include site selection and design, site preparation, plant selection, planting methods and maintenance, pollinator ID, and plant ID. The goal of this workshop series is to provide participants with the tools and knowledge to transform small areas of unused land (e.g. home, school, and church yards) into native pollinator habitat. Participants must commit to both workshop dates.

title: Writing in the Galleries
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in on the first floor
description: In this workshop, we begin by looking closely at artwork—asking what we see, think, feel, and wonder. Together, we'll explore the artist's possible message and its social meaning, then turn those reflections into our own creative responses.  Whether you're a writer or simply curious to try something new, you'll find inspiration here and a welcoming community to share the journey.  What to Bringyour favorite pencil (no pens).  a notebook or paper. Clipboards are available to borrow.  a phone or camera to take a picture of the art for later reference.  Know Before You GoArrive early, check in, and get ready for an on-time start.Readwhere to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines.About Your Facilitator  Dedaimia Whitney earned an MFA in fiction from Indiana University under the direction of Scott Russell Sanders. She taught creative writing at Franklin College for many years. She has served the museum as a docent since 2019. Her favorite works of art are those that are both visually stimulating and thought-provoking.

title: Beginner/Intermediate Drawing Workshop
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in with Guest Services on the first floor
description: Reserve your spot. If this page says, "Registration has closed" that means the waitlist is full.SuppliesBring your favorite drawing pencil (e.g. 4B), a sketchbook or drawing paper, and a phone or device to photograph artwork (without flash) as we sketch.  Know Before You GoArrive early to find parking, check in, and get your drawing supplies ready.  At 1:55 p.m. any unclaimed reservations will be released to guests who are standing by waiting for a spot.  Where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines (https://artmuseum.indiana.edu/visit/your-visit.html).  This workshop is recommended for ages 12 and up. Anyone under 18, who is not an IU student, must be accompanied by an adult.  When You ArriveCheck in with Guest Services at the information desk on the first floor, even if you come often and even if you are late. We appreciate having an accurate attendance count.  Store all backpacks and large bags before entering the galleries. A small handbag may be carried at your side.  Get your supplies ready. Attach an 18x24" piece of newsprint to a drawing board.  Cancellations  This workshop often has a waitlist. Please use the cancellation link included with your confirmation email if your plans change.About the Instructor  John Cheek has taught credit and non-credit classes for eight years in portrait painting, landscape painting, palette knife painting, life drawing, beginning drawing, and advanced drawing, as well as in design. He volunteers his time and expertise to facilitate drawing workshops at the Eskenazi Museum of Art.

title: Family Art Lab
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Roehm Family Art-making Studio
description: Please note that this month's Family Art Lab does not follow the second Sunday schedule.  Designed for K-12 students and their families, this event offers a fun and flexible way to spark creativity and connect with each other. All ages and experience levels are welcome!  Come and go at your own pace. We recommend planning for at least an hour to explore the gallery and make art.  Start in the Art Studio inside the Kimberly and John Simpson Center for Education on the museum's 2nd floor to pick up your Gallery Challenge. Then head to the galleries to find the artwork we'll use as inspiration for our project! When you're ready, head back to the studio for our hands-on art-making activity that everyone will love.  This program takes place every Second Sunday of the month, excluding holidays and museum closures. Each month features new artworks and materials, so there's always something fresh to explore and create!  All children must be chaperoned.Know Before You Go:Read about where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines.Strollers are welcome in the galleries. When carrying small children, please keep them in front of you.  To save time at the lockers, avoid bringing backpacks or large bags.  When You Arrive:If you parked in the IMU parking lot, Guest Services can validate your parking voucher for a discount.  Store any large bags in the lockers behind the Guest Services desk.  Head upstairs to the 2nd Floor and into the Simpson Center for Education to start.  When in the galleries, do not touch the artwork. Be mindful to keep body parts and anything you're carrying at least 18" away from the art.  Photography is welcome! Just no flash or selfie sticks.

title: Exploring Music in Art
location: Eskenazi Museum of Art - Room Number: Check in at the information desk on the first floor
description: Depending on what's on view, this tour may include a Māori flute, Shiva (Lord of the Dance), drums from the Austral Islands and New Ireland, a Mayan bell, a Kango whistle, a Lumbo bow lute, a Mangbeta friction drum, an Egyptian castanet, sculptures of seated female Chinese musicians playing a pipa and a piaxiao, a biwat flute stop, and a gope board to play music from New Guinea sent to space on Voyager's Golden Record.    About your guide:  Kathie Durkel has volunteered as a Guide at the Eskenazi Museum of Art for more than ten years. She is the 2023 recipient of the Meier Award in recognition for her exemplary service, enthusiasm,and commitment to learning. She enjoys creating thematic tours, like this one.      Know Before You GoSpace is available for the first 12 people to check in with Guest Services on the day. Drop by the information desk on the first floor of the museum when you arrive.Strollers are welcome. A small handbag may be carried at your side. Backpacks and large bags will need to be stored before touring. Learn more aboutmuseum guidelines.If you park in the Indiana Memorial Union parking lot, Guest Services can validate your parking voucher for a discount.Read aboutwhere to find us and where to park,
source: Eskenazi Museum of Art, IU Jacobs School of Music

title: Lincoln's Declaration: How He Interpreted--and Defended--Our Founding Document
location: Unitarian Universalist Church, 2120 N Fee Ln, Bloomington, IN 47408, USA
description: In honor of its 250th Anniversary, John Schilb, Culbertson Chair and Professor Emeritus of English, will analyze Abraham Lincoln’s rhetoric regarding the Declaration of Independence. Many of Lincoln's opponents (e.g., Stephen Douglas and Jefferson Davis) either ridiculed the Declaration's claim that "all men are created equal" or believed that it applied just to whites. Lincoln maintained that "all" really did mean everyone. Only gradually, however, was he willing to consider Black people his social peers. Statements that he made during his debates with Douglas reflect this complex attitude. And even the Gettysburg Address does not assume that the Declaration's message has a future. Indeed, that speech called the Declaration's claim about equality a "proposition" to be tested. That is, Lincoln saw American democracy as something that might not endure. Its fate still seems in question, so his take on the Declaration remains timely.

title: 2nd Weekend Work Day Trail Building
description:
Knobstone Hiking Trail Association of Indiana Meetup
Would you to spend a day in some beautiful woods with a delightful group of people building a connecting section of Indiana’s premier long distance hiking trail? Come join us as we continue work on the Tecumseh Trail extension portion of the KHT in MMSF. We will be building the new trail including clipping green briar.
Please bring a lunch and water. We will have large hand tools, but please bring any small tools you have such as clippers or a pruning saw. And a backpack is handy to carry everything in. Instructions will be provided for those who need them. We finish about 3:30.
Meet at the Hatfield Ridge Road gate. The gate is locked but we have a key. Go to the big sign on Rosenbaum/Catholic Cemetry Rd.
Join us on our website at http://www.knobstonehikingtrail.org/, on Facebook at [www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484](http://www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484), and Substack [https://khta.substack.com/](https://khta.substack.com/)
source: Meetup Knobstone Hiking Trail Association Of Indiana Meetup

title: Finn: A New Musical- At the PB&J Cafe
location: Waldron Auditorium,122 South Walnut Street, Bloomington, IN 47404, USA
description:
Constellation Stage & Screen presents “Finn: A New Musical- At the PB&J Cafe,” on stage May 1-17 at the Waldron Auditorium.

From the creator of Doc McStuffins and Vampirina, Finn is a heartwarming musical adventure about a young shark on the brink of growing up. As he prepares to join the fearsome Shark Guard, Finn can’t shake the feeling that he’s different from the other sharks. Deep inside, he discovers a colorful fish inside him—a part of himself that longs to sparkle, sing, and dance. As Finn embarks on a journey of self-discovery, friendship, and adventure, he finds the courage to be himself! Fun for all ages!

description:
Every Wednesday at 8PM is Comedy Attic Open Mic Night. Bloomington has one of the best local comedy scenes in the country, and it all starts with our open mic night!

Each comedian is asked to do no more than five minutes of completely original material. While we do not care about foul language in your set, we do not allow racist, homophobic, transphobic or rape/female bashing jokes. If you have to ask if it's racist, homophobic, transphobic or a rape joke, it probably is.

Comedians that wish to participate are asked to e-mail comedyattic@gmail.com mailto:comedyattic@gmail.com . Newcomers and any participants who are not paid professionals will be required to bring audience members to see them. This is non-negotiable. So if you plan on signing up, be sure to invite as many friends as you can. Good luck!

title: Homeschool Day: America 250
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART
description: Travel back in time with us to America in 1776 to meet George Washington and see the Declaration of Independence up close. Together, we'll explore the art and stories that shaped our nation's founding. Afterwards, we'll create our own colonial-inspired artwork in the studio, reflecting on the theme of "What America Means to Me."Know Before You Go:  Meet us on the 1st floor of the museum at 10 a.m. Together, we'll drop off personal items in the Simpson Center for Education before exploring the galleries. After seeing artworks that will inspire our project, we'll head back to the Roehm Family Art-Making Studio to create our own masterpieces! Don't forget to dress for a mess!  Strollers are welcome. Chaperones required. We ask that chaperones be 18 or older, with one adult for every 6 children.Parking Information:  The museum is in the pedestrian district of campus with several parking options nearby. The Indiana Memorial Union lot (900 E. 7th Street) is just a 5-minute walk diagonal to the museum, and visitors can receive 40% off parking validation at the museum's guest services desk. The East Garage (105 N. Eagleson Ave.) and Fee Lane Garage (709 N. Fee Lane) are also convenient, about an 8–10 minute walk. Learn more about parking on the Bloomington campus here (https://parking.indiana.edu/facilities/index.html).

Together, we'll explore the art and stories that shaped our nation's founding. Afterwards, we'll create our own colonial-inspired artwork in the studio, reflecting on the theme of "What America Means to Me."Know Before You Go:  Meet us on the 1st floor of the museum at 1 p.m. Together, we'll drop off personal items in the Simpson Center for Education before exploring the galleries. After seeing artworks that will inspire our project, we'll head back to the Roehm Family Art-Making Studio to create our own masterpieces! Don't forget to dress for a mess!  Strollers are welcome. title: Spring Moth Night
location: Griffy Lake Nature Preserve, 3400 N Headley Rd, Bloomington, IN 47408, USA
description:
Registration fee $6/in-city, $7/non-city. Register online by May 13 at https://webtrac.bloomington.in.gov/webtrac/web/search.html?Primarycode=140016. For ages 10 yrs. and up.
Late spring-early summer is an excellent time to observe moths. These insects overwinter in a pupal case under the leaf litter, and arise in the springtime as beautiful moths. Spring is the season when you are most likely to find cecropia and luna moths. Lets see what we can find! Participants should plan to bring portable seating and a flashlight and be able to hike on a moderate trail.

title: Color Drawing and Painting Workshop
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in with Guest Services on the first floor
description: Discover the joy of drawing in an inspiring setting! Begin by sketching directly from artwork in the collection to sharpen your eye and strengthen your skills. Then, move into the studio to learn about color theory and add color to your artwork.Strengthen fundamental drawing skills  Explore color theory in action  Experiment with color media  Expand your creative expression in a hands-on way  Reserve your spot. If this page says, "Registration has closed" that means the waitlist is full.SuppliesBring your favorite drawing pencil (e.g. 4B), a sketchbook or drawing paper, and a phone or device to photograph artwork (without flash) as we sketch. Additional supplies are provided.  Know Before You GoArrive early to find parking, check in, and get your drawing supplies ready.  At 1:55 p.m. any unclaimed reservations will be released to guests who are standing by waiting for a spot.  Where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines (https://artmuseum.indiana.edu/visit/your-visit.html).  This workshop is recommended for ages 12 and up. Anyone under 18, who is not an IU student, must be accompanied by an adult.  When You ArriveCheck in with Guest Services at the information desk on the first floor, even if you come often and even if you are late. We appreciate having an accurate attendance count.  Store all backpacks and large bags before entering the galleries. A small handbag may be carried at your side.  Get your supplies ready. Attach an 18x24" piece of newsprint to a drawing board.  Cancellations  This workshop often has a waitlist. Please use the cancellation link included with your confirmation email if your plans change.About the Instructor  John Cheek has taught credit and non-credit classes for eight years in portrait painting, landscape painting, palette knife painting, life drawing, beginning drawing, and advanced drawing, as well as in design. He volunteers his time and expertise to facilitate drawing workshops at the Eskenazi Museum of Art.

description:
Constellation Stage & Screen presents “Finn: A New Musical- At the PB&J Cafe,” on stage May 1-17 at the Waldron Auditorium.

From the creator of Doc McStuffins and Vampirina, Finn is a heartwarming musical adventure about a young shark on the brink of growing up. As he prepares to join the fearsome Shark Guard, Finn can’t shake the feeling that he’s different from the other sharks. Deep inside, he discovers a colorful fish inside him—a part of himself that longs to sparkle, sing, and dance. As Finn embarks on a journey of self-discovery, friendship, and adventure, he finds the courage to be himself! Fun for all ages!

PB&J Cafe: A Dinner Theater for Kids! At the PB&J Cafe, young theatergoers will enjoy a meal during the performance and leave with autographs from their favorite characters.

Constellation offers select sensory-friendly performances for our Constellation for Kids series. This special performance is designed to create a theater experience that is welcoming to all families with children with sensory sensitivities. Tickets to Constellation’s sensory-friendly performances are Pay What You Will https://seeconstellation.org/box-office/pwyw/ , meaning you get to choose your own ticket price (starting at $10, plus a $3 venue preservation fee). Sponsored by Unlocking the Spectrum https://unlockingthespectrum.com/ .


See Constellation’s website for more information, including a detailed performance schedule. Learn more and find tickets at seeconstellation.org/kids/finn/ https://seeconstellation.org/kids/finn/ https://seeconstellation.org/kids/finn/

title: Parents' Afternoon In at the Eskenazi Museum of Art
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART
description: Parents' Afternoon In offers a unique opportunity to enjoy the museum with separate parallel programming that supports creativity, and relaxation. Kids will have the opportunity to engage with art while parents relax with a variety of activities.  K-12 Children's Program12:00–12:30 PM: Guided gallery exploration.  12:30–2:00 PM: Hands-on art activity in the art studio + snack.  Adult Program12:00–1:00 PM: Experience select galleries through a fun and casual guided experience.  1:00–2:00 PM: Choose your own adventure: relax with art-filled coloring sheets, have a snack from the museum cafe or explore more of the galleries at your leisure.

title: Touch a Truck
description:
Explore interesting machinery and vehicles that help us build the big giant world around us! Fire trucks, semis, utility vehicles, buses, and more park and open their doors for children to climb, discover, and of course, turn on the very cool lights and sirens. Beginning with a sensory hour, we'll keep things calm and quiet with no flashing lights or loud noises from 10am - 11am, with the event open until 2pm. 

Geared towards children ages 1- 10 years.
Rain Date: Thursday, June 4 from 10 a.m. - 2 p.m.

title: Open Mic Night at The Comedy Attic
location: The Comedy Attic,123 S Walnut St, Bloomington, IN 47408, USA
description:
Every Wednesday at 8PM is Comedy Attic Open Mic Night. Bloomington has one of the best local comedy scenes in the country, and it all starts with our open mic night!

Each comedian is asked to do no more than five minutes of completely original material. While we do not care about foul language in your set, we do not allow racist, homophobic, transphobic or rape/female bashing jokes. If you have to ask if it's racist, homophobic, transphobic or a rape joke, it probably is.

Comedians that wish to participate are asked to e-mail comedyattic@gmail.com mailto:comedyattic@gmail.com . Newcomers and any participants who are not paid professionals will be required to bring audience members to see them. This is non-negotiable. So if you plan on signing up, be sure to invite as many friends as you can. Good luck!

title: Another Revolution
location: Constellation Playhouse,107 West 9th Street, Bloomington, IN 47404, USA
description:
Constellation Stage & Screen presents “Another Revolution,” on stage June 4-21 at the Constellation Playhouse.

Some revolutions happen in the streets. Others in the lab.

Kat and Henry, two graduate students from opposing scientific disciplines, are forced to share a lab at Columbia University in 1968. Amidst interpersonal differences, a campus devolving into political chaos, and the uncertainty and turmoil of the outside world, they each discover what it’s like to be thrown into someone else’s orbit. By Jacqueline Bircher, playwright of Constellation’s hit production of Webster’s B!+@#. Recommended for ages 13+.


See Constellation’s website for more information, including a detailed performance schedule. Learn more and find tickets at seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/ https://seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/ https://seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/

title: Arts Mile
description:
Experience downtown Bloomington’s vibrant Arts Mile as select galleries showcase evolving live and virtual exhibits.

EVERY. FIRST. FRIDAY. Experience an exciting night of the arts as fourteen distinct galleries stay open late to host special exhibits and serve refreshments from 5-8pm.

Stroll the vibrant arts scene along the sensational art mile and experience amazing art by renowned local, regional, and international artists. Discover delightful surprises, inspiration, festivities, and original works of art for purchase. Explore each distinctive gallery in-person or online all year long at your own pace.

Click here to learn more https://www.gallerywalkbloomington.com/

title: Lemonade Day 2026
description:
Lemonade Day is a free, fun, experiential learning program that teaches youth how to start, own and operate their own business – a lemonade stand. 
The foremost objective of Lemonade Day is to empower youth to take ownership of their lives and become productive members of society – the business leaders, social advocates, volunteers, and forward thinking citizens of tomorrow. 
Each child that registers receives access to Lemonopolis, our FREE and FUN online curriculum that teaches them Lemonade Day lessons like creating budgets, setting profit-making goals, serving customers, repaying investors, and giving back to the community. Along the way, they acquire skills in goal-setting, problem solving, and gain self-esteem critical for future success. They also receive additional digital content from local sponsors and experts on topics like Building a Lemonade Stand, Recipe Exploration, Marketing, and more!

title: Writing in the Galleries
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in on the first floor
description: In this workshop, we begin by looking closely at artwork—asking what we see, think, feel, and wonder. Together, we'll explore what we think the artist is trying to say and what the social significance of their message might be. Then we'll use our imaginations to respond to any aspect of our experience. Poets, story-tellers, and essayists are all welcome in this group!  What to Bringyour favorite pencil (no pens).  a notebook or paper. Clipboards are available to borrow.  a phone or camera to take a picture of the art for later reference.  Know Before You GoArrive early, check in, and get ready for an on-time start.Readwhere to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines.About Your Facilitator  Dedaimia Whitney earned an MFA in fiction from Indiana University under the direction of Scott Russell Sanders. She taught creative writing at Franklin College for many years. She has served the museum as a docent since 2019. Her favorite works of art are those that are both visually stimulating and thought-provoking.

title: Beginner/Intermediate Drawing Workshop
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in with Guest Services on the first floor
description: Reserve your spot. If this page says, "Registration has closed" that means the waitlist is full.SuppliesBring your favorite drawing pencil (e.g. 4B), a sketchbook or drawing paper, and a phone or device to photograph artwork (without flash) as we sketch.  Know Before You GoArrive early to find parking, check in, and get your drawing supplies ready.  At 1:55 p.m. any unclaimed reservations will be released to guests who are standing by waiting for a spot.  Where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines (https://artmuseum.indiana.edu/visit/your-visit.html).  This workshop is recommended for ages 12 and up. Anyone under 18, who is not an IU student, must be accompanied by an adult.  When You ArriveCheck in with Guest Services at the information desk on the first floor, even if you come often and even if you are late. We appreciate having an accurate attendance count.  Store all backpacks and large bags before entering the galleries. A small handbag may be carried at your side.  Get your supplies ready. Attach an 18x24" piece of newsprint to a drawing board.  Cancellations  This workshop often has a waitlist. Please use the cancellation link included with your confirmation email if your plans change.About the Instructor  John Cheek has taught credit and non-credit classes for eight years in portrait painting, landscape painting, palette knife painting, life drawing, beginning drawing, and advanced drawing, as well as in design. He volunteers his time and expertise to facilitate drawing workshops at the Eskenazi Museum of Art.

title: 2nd Weekend Work Day Trail Building
description:
Knobstone Hiking Trail Association of Indiana Meetup
Would you to spend a day in some beautiful woods with a delightful group of people building a connecting section of Indiana’s premier long distance hiking trail? Come join us as we continue work on the Tecumseh Trail extension portion of the KHT in MMSF. We will be building the new trail including clipping green briar.
Please bring a lunch and water. We will have large hand tools, but please bring any small tools you have such as clippers or a pruning saw. And a backpack is handy to carry everything in. Instructions will be provided for those who need them. We finish about 3:30.
Meet at the Hatfield Ridge Road gate. The gate is locked but we have a key. Go to the big sign on Rosenbaum/Catholic Cemetry Rd.
Join us on our website at http://www.knobstonehikingtrail.org/, on Facebook at [www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484](http://www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484), and Substack [https://khta.substack.com/](https://khta.substack.com/)
source: Meetup Knobstone Hiking Trail Association Of Indiana Meetup

title: Relaxing with Landscapes
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: check in with Guest Services at the information desk on the first floor
description: Cool down your body while heating up your mind as we discuss what we see as a group, helping each other discover details we might otherwise miss in a quick visit through the galleries.    About Your Guide  Dr. TammyJo Eckhart is an ancient historian who has enjoyed being part of the Eskenazi Guide Program since 2009. She was the 2025 recipient of the Patricia and Joel Meier Guide Award from that program. She looks forward to sitting with you and really spending time with these wonderful landscapes.    Know Before You Go  Space is available for the first 12 people to check in with Guest Services on the day. Drop by the information desk on the first floor of the museum when you arrive.A small handbag may be carried at your side. Backpacks and large bags will need to be stored before touring. Learn more aboutmuseum guidelines.If you park in the IMU parking lot, Guest Services can validate your parking voucher for a discount.Read aboutwhere to find us and where to park,

description:
Constellation Stage & Screen presents “Another Revolution,” on stage June 4-21 at the Constellation Playhouse.

Some revolutions happen in the streets. Others in the lab.

Kat and Henry, two graduate students from opposing scientific disciplines, are forced to share a lab at Columbia University in 1968. See Constellation’s website for more information, including a detailed performance schedule. Learn more and find tickets at seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/ https://seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/ https://seeconstellation.org/mainstage/another-revolution/

title: Intermediate/Advanced Drawing Workshop
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in with Guest Services on the first floor
description: Reserve your spot. If this page says, "Registration has closed" that means the waitlist is full.SuppliesBring your favorite drawing pencil (e.g. 4B), a sketchbook or drawing paper, and a phone or device to photograph artwork (without flash) as we sketch.  Know Before You GoArrive early to find parking, check in, and get your drawing supplies ready.  At 1:55 p.m. any unclaimed reservations will be released to guests who are standing by waiting for a spot.  Where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines (https://artmuseum.indiana.edu/visit/your-visit.html).  This workshop is recommended for ages 12 and up. Anyone under 18, who is not an IU student, must be accompanied by an adult.  When You ArriveCheck in with Guest Services at the information desk on the first floor, even if you come often and even if you are late. We appreciate having an accurate attendance count.  Store all backpacks and large bags before entering the galleries. A small handbag may be carried at your side.  Get your supplies ready. Attach an 18x24" piece of newsprint to a drawing board.  Cancellations  This workshop often has a waitlist. Please use the cancellation link included with your confirmation email if your plans change.About the Instructor  John Cheek has taught credit and non-credit classes for eight years in portrait painting, landscape painting, palette knife painting, life drawing, beginning drawing, and advanced drawing, as well as in design. He volunteers his time and expertise to facilitate drawing workshops at the Eskenazi Museum of Art.

title: 2nd Weekend Work Day Trail Building
description:
Knobstone Hiking Trail Association of Indiana Meetup
Would you to spend a day in some beautiful woods with a delightful group of people building a connecting section of Indiana’s premier long distance hiking trail? Come join us as we continue work on the Tecumseh Trail extension portion of the KHT in MMSF. We will be building the new trail including clipping green briar.
Please bring a lunch and water. We will have large hand tools, but please bring any small tools you have such as clippers or a pruning saw. And a backpack is handy to carry everything in. Instructions will be provided for those who need them. We finish about 3:30.
Meet at the Hatfield Ridge Road gate. The gate is locked but we have a key. Go to the big sign on Rosenbaum/Catholic Cemetry Rd.
Join us on our website at http://www.knobstonehikingtrail.org/, on Facebook at [www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484](http://www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484), and Substack [https://khta.substack.com/](https://khta.substack.com/)
source: Meetup Knobstone Hiking Trail Association Of Indiana Meetup

description:
Our Teen Programs are hosting our annual Pancake Breakfast, coming up in just a few weeks! The breakfast will be on Saturday July 26th at BJ’s Brewhouse located at 411 S. College Mall Road. The event will be from 8:00-10:00 am. And the best part?? It’s only $5 per ticket!! And that $5 goes towards supporting our teens! 
Our Pancake Breakfast is way more than just a simple breakfast–this innovative program teaches Club Teens how to take responsibility for THEIR teen program by raising money. It also teaches them sales, customer service, confidence and teamwork!
Tickets are available at our Lincoln Street, Ellettsville, & Ferguson Crestmont Clubs for only $5

title: Curator-led Tour
location: SIDNEY AND LOIS ESKENAZI MUSEUM OF ART - Room Number: Check in with Guest Services on the first floor
description: Step into the world of acclaimed photographer Rania Matar (b. 1964, Lebanon), whose striking portraits document young women persisting in uncertain times. Matar's lens highlights women's creativity, strength, dignity, and resilience—offering a powerful counter-narrative to the challenges of her country and region. Read more about this featured exhibition (https://artmuseum.indiana.edu/exhibitions/upcoming/_feature-exhibitions/2026-03-05-rania-matar-where-do-i-go.html).  Join us for a rare opportunity to explore the artist's work in depth, guided by the scholar who researched and curated the exhibition. Read Leila Reichert's bio. (http://Elliot%20Josephine%20Leila%20Reichert%20is%20an%20American%20curator,%20critic,%20and%20editor.%20She%20is%20the%20inaugural%20Curator%20of%20Contemporary%20Art%20at%20the%20Eskenazi%20Museum%20of%20Art%20at%20Indiana%20University%20and%20was%20a%202023-24%20Propel%20Fellow%20with%20the%20Association%20of%20Art%20Museum%20Curators%20Foundation.%20She%20was%20formerly%20Art%20Editor%20of%20Newcity%20and%20Assistant%20Curator%20at%20the%20Block%20Museum%20of%20Art,%20Northwestern%20University.%20She%20has%20curated%20and%20assisted%20in%20developing%20critically%20celebrated%20exhibitions%20in%20the%20United%20States%20and%20abroad.%20Her%20critical%20writing%20has%20been%20published%20in%20the%20Journal%20of%20Visual%20Studies,%20Hyperallergic,%20the%20Brooklyn%20Rail,%20Newcity%20Art,%20and%20The%20Seen,%20among%20others.%20She%20holds%20dual%20masters%E2%80%99%20degrees%20in%20Modern%20and%20Contemporary%20Art%20History%20and%20Arts%20Administration%20and%20Cultural%20Policy%20from%20the%20School%20of%20the%20Art%20Institute%20of%20Chicago%20and%20a%20Bachelors%20of%20Arts%20with%20Honors%20in%20Art%20History%20from%20Northwestern%20University,%20where%20she%20graduated%20summa%20cum%20laude.)  Reserve your spot today for a chance to connect with Rania Matar's striking photographs in a personal, meaningful way. Leila will share the stories, research, and insights behind the exhibition, making this experience as memorable as the photography itself.Know Before You GoSpace is limited to 15 participants. RSVP to reserve a space. Walk-ins are welcome if space is available. If this page says "registration has closed", this means that registration and the waitlist have filled for this date and time.Plan to arrive early to check in. At 1:25 p.m., any unclaimed spaces may be released to guests who are standing by waiting for a space.Admission and tours are free.A small handbag may be carried at your side. Larger bags and backpacks will need to be stored before touring.Read about where to find us, where to park, accessibility, and museum guidelines.When You ArriveCheck in with Guest Services staff on the first floor.If you park in the IMU parking lot, Guest Services can validate your parking voucher for a discount.Be sure to store backpacks and large bags before touring. Lockers and coat racks are available.Keep space (18") between yourself, including anything you're carrying, and the art.

title: Arts Mile
description:
Experience downtown Bloomington’s vibrant Arts Mile as select galleries showcase evolving live and virtual exhibits.

EVERY. FIRST. FRIDAY. Experience an exciting night of the arts as fourteen distinct galleries stay open late to host special exhibits and serve refreshments from 5-8pm.

Stroll the vibrant arts scene along the sensational art mile and experience amazing art by renowned local, regional, and international artists. Discover delightful surprises, inspiration, festivities, and original works of art for purchase. Explore each distinctive gallery in-person or online all year long at your own pace.

Click here to learn more https://www.gallerywalkbloomington.com/

title: 2nd Weekend Work Day Trail Building
description:
Knobstone Hiking Trail Association of Indiana Meetup
Would you to spend a day in some beautiful woods with a delightful group of people building a connecting section of Indiana’s premier long distance hiking trail? Come join us as we continue work on the Tecumseh Trail extension portion of the KHT in MMSF. We will be building the new trail including clipping green briar.
Please bring a lunch and water. We will have large hand tools, but please bring any small tools you have such as clippers or a pruning saw. And a backpack is handy to carry everything in. Instructions will be provided for those who need them. We finish about 3:30.
Meet at the Hatfield Ridge Road gate. The gate is locked but we have a key. Go to the big sign on Rosenbaum/Catholic Cemetry Rd.
Join us on our website at http://www.knobstonehikingtrail.org/, on Facebook at [www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484](http://www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484), and Substack [https://khta.substack.com/](https://khta.substack.com/)
source: Meetup Knobstone Hiking Trail Association Of Indiana Meetup

title: Junk in the Trunk
description:
Junk in the Trunk is recycling and treasure hunting...at the same time! Visit inside and outside the Switchyard Park Pavilion for yard sale vendors that are set up to sell furniture, books, clothing, toys, household goods, and more.  

Want a booth space? Sign up online by choosing either an indoor or outdoor booth; spaces are approximately 10x10 each; vendors may reserve up to three booth spaces each. Indoor spaces sell out quickly! Outdoor spaces are on the brick plaza on the north side of the Pavilion. Registration for the August Junk in the Trunk will open at 8am on May 4, 2026

title: Bloomington Community Farmers' Market
location: City of Bloomington, 401 N Morton St, Bloomington, IN 47404, USA
description:
The Bloomington Community Farmers' Market takes place rain or shine every Saturday, April through October, at Showers Common next to City Hall, 401 N. Morton St. in Bloomington.

April-September: 8 a.m.-12:30 p.m.
October: 9 a.m.-12:30 p.m.
November: 9 a.m.-12:30 p.m. at the Pavilion at Switchyard Park

The Market is a gathering place where local farmers, makers, and neighbors come together to share the foods, traditions, and connections that strengthen our community and support a reliable local food supply.

Market goers find a wide assortment of goods from the farm and field, including fruits and vegetables, eggs, meats and cheeses, honey, seasonal flowers, and annual and perennial plants. Food and beverage artisans provide a tasteful variety of drinks, pastries, and savory dishes. This weekly gathering provides opportunities for individuals to connect with their community in meaningful ways and support local farmers and small businesses.

title: 2nd Weekend Work Day Trail Building
description:
Knobstone Hiking Trail Association of Indiana Meetup
Would you to spend a day in some beautiful woods with a delightful group of people building a connecting section of Indiana’s premier long distance hiking trail? Come join us as we continue work on the Tecumseh Trail extension portion of the KHT in MMSF. We will be building the new trail including clipping green briar.
Please bring a lunch and water. We will have large hand tools, but please bring any small tools you have such as clippers or a pruning saw. And a backpack is handy to carry everything in. Instructions will be provided for those who need them. We finish about 3:30.
Meet at the Hatfield Ridge Road gate. The gate is locked but we have a key. Go to the big sign on Rosenbaum/Catholic Cemetry Rd.
Join us on our website at http://www.knobstonehikingtrail.org/, on Facebook at [www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484](http://www.facebook.com/groups/2255586117953484), and Substack [https://khta.substack.com/](https://khta.substack.com/)
source: Meetup Knobstone Hiking Trail Association Of Indiana Meetup

title: Bloomington Community Farmers' Market
location: Switchyard Park, 1601 S Rogers St, Bloomington, IN 47403, USA
description:
The Bloomington Community Farmers' Market takes place rain or shine every Saturday, April through October, at Showers Common next to City Hall, 401 N. Morton St. in Bloomington.

April-September: 8 a.m.-12:30 p.m.
October: 9 a.m.-12:30 p.m.
November: 9 a.m.-12:30 p.m. at the Pavilion at Switchyard Park

The Market is a gathering place where local farmers, makers, and neighbors come together to share the foods, traditions, and connections that strengthen our community and support a reliable local food supply.

Market goers find a wide assortment of goods from the farm and field, including fruits and vegetables, eggs, meats and cheeses, honey, seasonal flowers, and annual and perennial plants. Food and beverage artisans provide a tasteful variety of drinks, pastries, and savory dishes. This weekly gathering provides opportunities for individuals to connect with their community in meaningful ways and support local farmers and small businesses.

title: Board of Park Commissioners Meeting
location: City of Bloomington, 401 N Morton St, Bloomington, IN 47404, USA
description:
The Board of Park Commissioners is a policy-making authority for the City of Bloomington Parks and Recreation Department. The Board is comprised of four members appointed by the Mayor.

Statutory Authority: (I.C. 36-10-4) (BMC 2.20)

The Board meets at Bloomington's City Hall at 5 p.m. on the third Thursday of the month, with some exceptions for holidays.

See meeting agendas and notes from the Board of Park Commissioners online at https://bloomington.in.gov/boards/park-commissioners

For more information about the Board of Park Commissioners, send an email to Parks and Recreation Department Director Tim Street or call 812-349-3700.

Each comedian is asked to do no more than five minutes of completely original material. While we do not care about foul language in your set, we do not allow racist, homophobic, transphobic or rape/female bashing jokes. If you have to ask if it's racist, homophobic, transphobic or a rape joke, it probably is.

Comedians that wish to participate are asked to e-mail comedyattic@gmail.com mailto:comedyattic@gmail.com . Newcomers and any participants who are not paid professionals will be required to bring audience members to see them. This is non-negotiable. So if you plan on signing up, be sure to invite as many friends as you can. Good luck!

EVERY. FIRST. FRIDAY. Experience an exciting night of the arts as fourteen distinct galleries stay open late to host special exhibits and serve refreshments from 5-8pm.

Stroll the vibrant arts scene along the sensational art mile and experience amazing art by renowned local, regional, and international artists. Discover delightful surprises, inspiration, festivities, and original works of art for purchase. Explore each distinctive gallery in-person or online all year long at your own pace.

Click here to learn more https://www.gallerywalkbloomington.com/
